posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked:
We had an issue with our radio after robot hit a cage. Communication was lost, wires remained intact (network and power).

Quick diagnostics post match indicated it should be communicating yet couldn’t. We switched the radio out for future matches but now are hoping to do a deep diagnostic check.

WCP number is listed as support number but so far have not been able to speak to anyone there. Anyone know if there is any other number for hardware support for the radio?

Its an expensive radio to need to have multiple back ups on hand.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: The WCP number is correct, there is also an email for support listed on the documentation website. https://frc-radio.vivid-hosting.net/overview/support

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked: The issue has been forwarded from WCP support to vivid-hosting to further investigate.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: @kiettyyyy may know more or be able to help. I’d reach out to him directly.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
How and where was the radio mounted in the robot? Do you have photos you can share?

There were a few robots I did inspection on this last weekend where their radios were installed where they could easily sustain damage from other robots hitting their robot or their robot hitting some part of the field. Some of them did move their radio to a more protected location.

We had to call at different times of day and on different days to reach someone at WCP . They appear to be run by just a few people, each wearing many hats.

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked:
Video of Cage Contact (time stamp 1:10)

Robot_447_radio 400×754 376 KB

Robot_447_radio 400×754 376 KB

Robot_447_radio 400×754 376 KB

The radio is mounted to a 1/8" aluminum plate offers a bit of protection beyond the edge of the radio as it takes the hit before the radio would. The camera mounted next to it was not moved out of place either.

As you can see in the video, the cage did not swing into us, rather we pushed “out of the way” but it caught on the camera/radio mount.

The purpose of this thread is to see if the radio is possibly salvageable or if it is likely dead now. We have a second and will order another if we need to.

We understand that things happen, and hitting the radio with a steel cage is not an intended use case.

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked:
I was able to speak to WCP support today, they have suggested reflashing the firmware as a next step. The idea is while we had power to the radio by the time we got to the field to remove the robot, it is possible during the hit the radio may have lost power and corrupted the firmware.

Vivid-Hosting Support has also begun looking at the issue and responded to us via email following up on a CSA inquiry that was sent on our behalf following the event.

I will update this thread with the results of the reflashing attempt in case others experience something similar.

EDIT: The radio never reaches a state that we can access it’s firmware page. So reflashing, through methods we know about is not possible.

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked:
We opened the radio case tonight and found the two boards inside had pulled apart. It appears these are press fit together and during the course of the match in question, hitting the cage, enough force was applied to them they came loose.

We pressed them back together and the radio came back to life.

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked:
b9d41a60-d2a0-42b3-aad2-8a4ec3147511 636×1377 46.9 KB

b9d41a60-d2a0-42b3-aad2-8a4ec3147511 636×1377 46.9 KB

b9d41a60-d2a0-42b3-aad2-8a4ec3147511 636×1377 46.9 KB

Here is the picture of the radio with the case removed. Once we snapped it back together it powered on and functioned.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
High shock forces will do that sort of thing. It is not really possible to prevent that in the development phase without performing (repeated) vibration and shock tests in a properly equipped lab.

If possible, I would suggest keeping that particular radio as a backup or for practice only. Sometimes, the stress may cause microscopic cracks in the circuit board and/or solder joints. Unfortunately, there is no easy way to detect such damage. Further shock forces from “combat” may cause the cracks to get worse, leading to failures.

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked:
Vivid Hosting is going to RMA this radio. Our plan was, and for now may still be, to use it as the access point and move our access point radio to the robot. This radio will not go back into competition for the reasons you stated.

Happy that Vivid Hosting is willing to swap it out, still working on the logistics of how we do that and not be without the radio set up for a week.

Yes I realize we can use the single radio in a practice configuration (not ideal) or we could put last years radio on the robot for practice (even less ideal).

posts.name: RockRGI
posts.cooked:
Final update and shout out to West Coast Products and VIvid-Hosting.

We much appreciate the time and effort to help us in this matter and it has been resolved from our teams perspective very well.

Once we got the support process initiated things went smooth. End result is I don’t know exactly why the radio failed the way it did but Vivid-Hosting will have our radio in had in a few days to look over in their lab. They have a refurbished radio in route to us and we picked up an additional radio today to get on the robot this afternoon.

Thank you to all involved in the process!
